summary.text_en: Hippocrates is 'Father of Medicine'! He liberated medicine from superstition and witchcraft, establishing observation and reason-based medical system. He proposed diseases have natural causes, not divine punishment. Famous 'Hippocratic Oath' still foundation of medical ethics today.
key_points_en: Transformed medicine from superstition to science
Proposed natural causation theory of disease

story.text_en: Around 400 BC, Hippocrates practiced medicine on Kos island. People then believed diseases were divine punishment, treatment through prayer and sacrifice. Hippocrates said: 'Diseases are not sacred, but have natural causes.' He carefully observed patient symptoms, recorded disease progression, sought patterns. He established medical school, teaching students to be honest, humble, respect patients. He said: 'First, do no harm.' This became core principle of medical ethics.

fun_facts.text_en: Hippocratic Oath 2400 years old, modern medical students still recite it (adapted version) at graduation.
He diagnosed diseases by smelling patient's sweat, urine, wound odors - some methods still valid today!
'Hippocratic Corpus' has over 60 works, but likely only few actually written by him.
He emphasized environment, diet, lifestyle's impact on health - very advanced 2400 years ago!

experiment.title_en: Clinical Observation Method: Natural History of Disease
experiment.description_en: Hippocrates would sit by patient's bedside, observing condition changes for days. He recorded temperature, pulse, breathing, complexion, excretions details. He discovered many diseases have fixed progression patterns, like malaria recurring every other day. Through observing and comparing numerous cases, he summarized disease patterns, could predict course and outcome. This method pioneered evidence-based medicine.
experiment.why_en: Systematic observation and documentation reveal disease patterns, aiding diagnosis and prognosis - foundation of scientific medicine.

simple_explanation.text_en: Before Hippocrates, when people got sick they prayed at temples, believing gods were punishing them. Hippocrates said: 'No! Diseases have causes, we can find them through observation.' He was like detective, carefully observing patients, recording clues, seeking patterns. He also told doctors: 'Your job is helping patients, don't harm them, keep secrets.' These ideas sound simple, but 2400 years ago were revolutionary!

impact.text_en: Hippocrates transformed medicine from religious superstition to rational science, hailed as 'Father of Medicine'. His methodology of observation, documentation, analysis still foundation of medicine today. Hippocratic Oath's ethical principles - confidentiality, non-maleficence, serving patient interests - influenced every doctor for 2400 years. His thought is cornerstone of modern medicine.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ancient Egyptian medicine's anatomy and surgical knowledge
Rational thinking and natural philosophy methods

influenced.contribution_en: Modern clinical medicine inherited Hippocratic bedside teaching

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Hippocrates inherited ancient Egyptian medical knowledge and Pythagorean rational thinking, establishing scientific medical system. Galen developed anatomy and physiology on his foundation. Medieval Arab physician Avicenna preserved and spread Hippocratic works. Renaissance Vesalius re-studied human anatomy. Modern medicine father Osler inherited Hippocratic bedside teaching tradition.

quiz.question_en: What is the core principle of Hippocratic Oath?
quiz.explanation_en: 'First, do no harm' (Primum non nocere) is core of Hippocratic medical ethics. This means when treating, doctor's primary consideration is not causing additional harm to patient. This principle still cornerstone of medical ethics today, reminding doctors to practice cautiously, weighing treatment benefits and risks.
